sn15.19:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.19:1.3.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.19:1.3.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.19:1.4.pli: Na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo na dhītābhūtapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā.
sn15.19:1.4.eng: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your daughter.

sn15.19:1.6.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.19:1.7.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.19:1.7.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.19:1.8.pli: Evaṃ dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ tibbaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ byasanaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ, kaṭasī vaḍḍhitā.
sn15.19:1.8.eng: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.

sn15.19:1.9.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.19:1.9.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.2:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.2:1.3.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.2:1.3.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.2:1.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso imaṃ mahāpathaviṃ kolaṭṭhimattaṃ kolaṭṭhimattaṃ mattikāguḷikaṃ karitvā nikkhipeyya:
sn15.2:1.4.eng: Suppose a person was to make the whole earth into clay balls the size of jujube seeds. They’d lay them down, saying:

sn15.2:1.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ me pitā, tassa me pitu ayaṃ pitā’ti, apariyādinnāva bhikkhave, tassa purisassa pitupitaro assu, athāyaṃ mahāpathavī parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya.
sn15.2:1.5.eng: ‘This is my father, this is my grandfather.’ The whole earth would run out before that person’s fathers and grandfathers.

sn15.2:1.7.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.2:1.8.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.2:1.8.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.2:1.9.pli: Evaṃ dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ tibbaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ byasanaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ, kaṭasī vaḍḍhitā.
sn15.2:1.9.eng: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.

sn15.2:1.10.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.2:1.10.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.20:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn15.20:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn15.20:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn15.20:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.20:2.2.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.20:2.2.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.20:2.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘pācīnavaṃso’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:2.3.eng: Once upon a time, mendicants, this Mount Vepulla was known as Pācīnavaṁsa.
sn15.20:2.3.comm: For Vepulla, see SN 15.10:2.2. | A pācīnavaṁsa was a hall or shed built for the ritual, with bamboo (vaṁsa) beams running easterly (pācīna; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.1.6 and Eggeling’s note). Perhaps the mountain was noted as the site for the introduction of this ritual institution. In the Buddha’s day, there was a “Park of the East-Raftered Hall” in Cetī (MN 128:8.1, AN 8.30:1.2).

sn15.20:2.4.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ ‘tivarā’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:2.4.eng: And at that time people were known as Tivaras.
sn15.20:2.4.comm: Tivara may be connected to Vedic trivarūtha, the “triple defence”. This may be connected with the fortifications for which Rājagaha is famous. But by Vedic times it acquired a religious sense, here suggesting the people who have the protection of the gods due to their correct performance of the ritual in their hall. The “triple defence” can be seen as a precursor of the Buddhist triple refuge.

sn15.20:2.5.pli: Tivarānaṃ, bhikkhave, manussānaṃ cattārīsa vassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
sn15.20:2.5.eng: The lifespan of the Tivaras was 40,000 years.
sn15.20:2.5.comm: For the long lifespans of humans in the past, see AN 7.74:9.1. Declining lifespans are charted at DN 26:14.2.

sn15.20:2.6.pli: Tivarā, bhikkhave, manussā pācīnavaṃsaṃ pabbataṃ catūhena ārohanti, catūhena orohanti.
sn15.20:2.6.eng: It took them four days to climb Mount Vepulla, and four days to descend.

sn15.20:2.7.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno hoti.
sn15.20:2.7.eng: At that time Kakusandha, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
sn15.20:2.7.comm: Kakusandha and the other Buddhas are mentioned at SN 12.7–10. His lifespan of 40,000 years is confirmed at DN 14:1.7.4.

sn15.20:2.8.pli: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa vidhurasañjīvaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
sn15.20:2.8.eng: Kakusandha had a fine pair of chief disciples named Vidhura and Sañjīva.
sn15.20:2.8.comm: The pairs of disciples are listed at DN 14:1.9.1. A story of Sañjīva is given at MN 50:9.2.

sn15.20:2.9.pli: Passatha, bhikkhave, sā cevimassa pabbatassa samaññā antarahitā, te ca manussā kālaṅkatā, so ca bhagavā parinibbuto.
sn15.20:2.9.eng: See, mendicants! This mountain’s name has vanished, those people have passed away, and that Buddha has become fully quenched.

sn15.20:2.13.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccituṃ.
sn15.20:2.13.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.

sn15.20:3.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘vaṅkako’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:3.1.eng: Once upon a time this Mount Vepulla was known as Vaṅkaka.

sn15.20:3.2.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ ‘rohitassā’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:3.2.eng: And at that time people were known as Rohitassas.
sn15.20:3.2.comm: These two terms are found in Rig Veda 4.6.9, “red horses going straight, going well” (rohitāsa ṛjvañcaḥ svañcaḥ), where rohitassa is the “red horse” of the sunbeams (SN 2.26), and Sanskrit vañca is evidently found in Pali vaṅka in the sense “going” (unless it is from vañcati, “fire”). Perhaps the mountain was named for the flashing beams of sunlight that broke over it at dawn.

sn15.20:3.3.pli: Rohitassānaṃ, bhikkhave, manussānaṃ tiṃsavassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
sn15.20:3.3.eng: The lifespan of the Rohitassas was 30,000 years.

sn15.20:3.4.pli: Rohitassā, bhikkhave, manussā vaṅkakaṃ pabbataṃ tīhena ārohanti, tīhena orohanti.
sn15.20:3.4.eng: It took them three days to climb Mount Vepulla, and three days to descend.

sn15.20:3.5.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena koṇāgamano bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno hoti.
sn15.20:3.5.eng: At that time Koṇāgamana, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
sn15.20:3.5.comm: His lifespan is confirmed at DN 14:1.7.5.

sn15.20:3.6.pli: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bhiyyosuttaraṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
sn15.20:3.6.eng: Koṇāgamana had a fine pair of chief disciples named Bhiyyosa and Uttara.

sn15.20:3.7.pli: Passatha, bhikkhave, sā cevimassa pabbatassa samaññā antarahitā, te ca manussā kālaṅkatā, so ca bhagavā parinibbuto.
sn15.20:3.7.eng: See, mendicants! This mountain’s name has vanished, those people have passed away, and that Buddha has become fully quenched.

sn15.20:4.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘supasso’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:4.1.eng: Once upon a time this Mount Vepulla was known as Supassa.
sn15.20:4.1.comm: Supassa is “Fairslope”, a name used for several mountains, including one on the eastern side of mount Meru.

sn15.20:4.2.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ ‘suppiyā’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:4.2.eng: And at that time people were known as Suppiyas.

sn15.20:4.3.pli: Suppiyānaṃ, bhikkhave, manussānaṃ vīsativassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
sn15.20:4.3.eng: The lifespan of the Suppiyas was 20,000 years.

sn15.20:4.4.pli: Suppiyā, bhikkhave, manussā supassaṃ pabbataṃ dvīhena ārohanti, dvīhena orohanti.
sn15.20:4.4.eng: It took them two days to climb Mount Vepulla, and two days to descend.

sn15.20:4.5.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno hoti.
sn15.20:4.5.eng: At that time Kassapa, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
sn15.20:4.5.comm: Stories of Kassapa, the Buddha immediately preceding Gotama, are found at MN 81 and AN 5.180.His lifespan is given at DN 14:1.7.6,

sn15.20:4.6.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tissabhāradvājaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
sn15.20:4.6.eng: Kassapa had a fine pair of chief disciples named Tissa and Bhāradvāja.

sn15.20:4.7.pli: Passatha, bhikkhave, sā cevimassa pabbatassa samaññā antarahitā, te ca manussā kālaṅkatā, so ca bhagavā parinibbuto.
sn15.20:4.7.eng: See, mendicants! This mountain’s name has vanished, those people have passed away, and that Buddha has become fully quenched.

sn15.20:5.1.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘vepullo’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:5.1.eng: These days this Mount Vepulla is known as Vepulla.

sn15.20:5.2.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhikkhave, imesaṃ manussānaṃ ‘māgadhakā’tveva samaññā udapādi.
sn15.20:5.2.eng: And these people are known as Magadhans.

sn15.20:5.3.pli: Māgadhakānaṃ, bhikkhave, manussānaṃ appakaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ parittaṃ lahukaṃ;
sn15.20:5.3.eng: The lifespan of the Magadhans is short, brief, and fleeting.

sn15.20:5.4.pli: yo ciraṃ jīvati so vassasataṃ appaṃ vā bhiyyo.
sn15.20:5.4.eng: A long life is a hundred years or a little more.

sn15.20:5.5.pli: Māgadhakā, bhikkhave, manussā vepullaṃ pabbataṃ muhuttena ārohanti muhuttena orohanti.
sn15.20:5.5.eng: It takes the Magadhans an hour to climb Mount Vepulla, and an hour to descend.
sn15.20:5.5.comm: Kauṭilya says there are fifteen muhuttas (Sanskrit muhūrta) per day, and fifteen per night, making 48 minutes (Arthaśāstra 2.20.37).

sn15.20:5.6.pli: Etarahi kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno.
sn15.20:5.6.eng: And now I am the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha who has arisen in the world.

sn15.20:5.7.pli: Mayhaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sāriputtamoggallānaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
sn15.20:5.7.eng: I have a fine pair of chief disciples named Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

sn15.20:5.8.pli: Bhavissati, bhikkhave, so samayo yā ayañcevimassa pabbatassa samaññā antaradhāyissati, ime ca manussā kālaṃ karissanti, ahañca parinibbāyissāmi.
sn15.20:5.8.eng: There will come a time when this mountain’s name will vanish, those people will die, and I will be fully extinguished.

sn15.20:5.12.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.20:5.12.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.20:6.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn15.20:6.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn15.20:6.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn15.20:8.2.eng: their nature is to rise and fall;

sn15.20:9.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the unknown beginning are complete.

sn15.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.3:1.3.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.3:1.3.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.3:1.4.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā vo iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ amanāpasampayogā manāpavippayogā kandantānaṃ rodantānaṃ assu passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, yaṃ vā catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakan”ti?
sn15.3:1.4.eng: What do you think? Which is more: the flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time—weeping and wailing from being coupled with the unloved and separated from the loved—or the water in the four oceans?”
sn15.3:1.4.comm: Each world system—or as we would say, solar system—has four oceans (AN 3.80:4.2). These were proverbial for an abundance of wealth (Rig Veda 9.33.6, 10.47.2; Atharva Veda 19.27.3). There are eastern and western oceans (RV 10.136.5, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.6.3.11; eastern sea at ŚB 10.6.4.1, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.1.2), and upper and lower (RV 7.6.7, 10.98.5). We can identify the eastern and western oceans as the Bay of Bengal and Arabian Sea, while the lower is the Indian Ocean, into which water flows from the upper heavenly ocean in the Himalayas.

sn15.3:1.5.pli: “Yathā kho mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāma, etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ yaṃ no iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ amanāpasampayogā manāpavippayogā kandantānaṃ rodantānaṃ assu passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakan”ti.
sn15.3:1.5.eng: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the flow of tears we’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”

sn15.3:2.1.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhave, sādhu kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha.
sn15.3:2.1.eng: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.

sn15.3:2.2.pli: Etadeva, bhikkhave, bahutaraṃ yaṃ vo iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ amanāpasampayogā manāpavippayogā kandantānaṃ rodantānaṃ assu passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
sn15.3:2.2.eng: The flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.

sn15.3:2.3.eng: For a long time you’ve undergone the death of a mother …

sn15.3:2.4.pli: tesaṃ vo mātumaraṇaṃ paccanubhontānaṃ amanāpasampayogā manāpavippayogā kandantānaṃ rodantānaṃ assu passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.

sn15.3:2.12.pli: Dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, rogabyasanaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ, tesaṃ vo rogabyasanaṃ paccanubhontānaṃ amanāpasampayogā manāpavippayogā kandantānaṃ rodantānaṃ assu passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
sn15.3:2.12.eng: or loss through illness. From being coupled with the unloved and separated from the loved, the flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.

sn15.3:2.14.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.3:2.15.pli: yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.3:2.15.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.4:1.3.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.4:1.3.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.4:1.4.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā vo iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ mātuthaññaṃ pītaṃ, yaṃ vā catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakan”ti?
sn15.4:1.4.eng: What do you think? Which is more: the mother’s milk you’ve drunk while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time, or the water in the four oceans?”

sn15.4:1.5.pli: “Yathā kho mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāma, etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ yaṃ no iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ mātuthaññaṃ pītaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakan”ti.
sn15.4:1.5.eng: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the mother’s milk we’ve drunk while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”

sn15.4:2.1.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhave, sādhu kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha.
sn15.4:2.1.eng: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.

sn15.4:2.2.pli: Etadeva, bhikkhave, bahutaraṃ yaṃ vo iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ mātuthaññaṃ pītaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
sn15.4:2.2.eng: The mother’s milk you’ve drunk while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time is more than the water in the four oceans.

sn15.4:2.4.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.4:2.5.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn15.5:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and asked him,

sn15.5:1.3.comm: Indian cosmology assumes a cyclic universe, where an “eon” is the time for an entire universe to come into existence, evolve, decay, then disappear.

sn15.5:1.5.pli: So na sukaro saṅkhātuṃ ettakāni vassāni iti vā, ettakāni vassasatāni iti vā, ettakāni vassasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni vassasatasahassāni iti vā”ti.
sn15.5:1.5.eng: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”

sn15.5:2.1.eng: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”

sn15.5:2.3.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, mahāselo pabbato yojanaṃ āyāmena yojanaṃ vitthārena yojanaṃ ubbedhena acchinno asusiro ekagghano.
sn15.5:2.3.eng: “Suppose there was a huge stone mountain, a league long, a league wide, and a league high, with no cracks or holes, one solid mass.

sn15.5:2.4.pli: Tamenaṃ puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena kāsikena vatthena sakiṃ sakiṃ parimajjeyya.
sn15.5:2.4.eng: And as each century passed someone would stroke it once with a fine cloth from Kāsi.

sn15.5:2.5.pli: Khippataraṃ kho so, bhikkhu, mahāselo pabbato iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, na tveva kappo.
sn15.5:2.5.eng: By this means the huge stone mountain would be worn away before the eon comes to an end.

sn15.5:2.6.eng: That’s how long an eon is.

sn15.5:2.7.pli: Evaṃ dīghānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, kappānaṃ neko kappo saṃsito, nekaṃ kappasataṃ saṃsitaṃ, nekaṃ kappasahassaṃ saṃsitaṃ, nekaṃ kappasatasahassaṃ saṃsitaṃ.
sn15.5:2.7.eng: And we’ve transmigrated through many such eons, many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands.

sn15.5:2.9.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.5:2.11.pli: yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhu, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.5:2.11.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn15.6:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn15.6:1.5.pli: So na sukaro saṅkhātuṃ ettakāni vassāni iti vā …pe… ettakāni vassasatasahassāni iti vā”ti.
sn15.6:1.5.eng: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
sn15.6:1.5.comm: The purpose of these similes is to impress on the mind the incomprehensible vastness of existence. While it is doubtful they were ever meant to be literal numbers, I have done the math in a few cases. By way of comparison, the age of the universe in modern physical cosmology is around 13.9 billion years.

sn15.6:2.1.eng: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”

sn15.6:2.3.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, āyasaṃ nagaraṃ yojanaṃ āyāmena yojanaṃ vitthārena yojanaṃ ubbedhena, puṇṇaṃ sāsapānaṃ guḷikābaddhaṃ.
sn15.6:2.3.eng: “Suppose there was an iron citadel, a league long, a league wide, and a league high, full of mustard seeds pressed into balls.

sn15.6:2.4.pli: Tato puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena ekamekaṃ sāsapaṃ uddhareyya.
sn15.6:2.4.eng: And as each century passed someone would remove a single mustard seed.

sn15.6:2.5.pli: Khippataraṃ kho so, bhikkhu, mahāsāsaparāsi iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, na tveva kappo.
sn15.6:2.5.eng: By this means the huge heap of mustard seeds would be used up before the eon comes to an end.
sn15.6:2.5.comm: Assuming 2mm per mustard seed, and 10km per league, that’s about 5×10²² years.

sn15.6:2.6.eng: That’s how long an eon is.

sn15.6:2.7.pli: Evaṃ dīghānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, kappānaṃ neko kappo saṃsito, nekaṃ kappasataṃ saṃsitaṃ, nekaṃ kappasahassaṃ saṃsitaṃ, nekaṃ kappasatasahassaṃ saṃsitaṃ.
sn15.6:2.7.eng: And we’ve transmigrated through many such eons, many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands.

sn15.6:2.9.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.6:2.10.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn15.7:1.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn15.7:1.3.pli: “kīvabahukā nu kho, bhante, kappā abbhatītā atikkantā”ti?

sn15.7:1.6.pli: ‘ettakā kappā iti vā, ettakāni kappasatāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasatasahassāni iti vā’”ti.
sn15.7:1.6.eng: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.”

sn15.7:2.1.eng: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”

sn15.7:2.3.eng: “Suppose there were four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years.

sn15.7:2.4.pli: Te divase divase kappasatasahassaṃ kappasatasahassaṃ anussareyyuṃ.
sn15.7:2.4.eng: And each day they would each recollect a hundred thousand eons.

sn15.7:2.5.pli: Ananussaritāva, bhikkhave, tehi kappā assu, atha kho te cattāro sāvakā vassasatāyukā vassasatajīvino vassasatassa accayena kālaṃ kareyyuṃ.
sn15.7:2.5.eng: Those four disciples would pass away after a hundred years and there would still be eons that they haven’t recollected.

sn15.7:2.6.pli: Evaṃ bahukā kho, bhikkhave, kappā abbhatītā atikkantā.
sn15.7:2.6.eng: That’s how many eons have passed.

sn15.7:2.8.pli: ‘ettakā kappā iti vā, ettakāni kappasatāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasatasahassāni iti vā’ti.
sn15.7:2.8.eng: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.

sn15.7:2.10.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.7:2.11.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.8:1.1.eng: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.

sn15.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn15.8:1.2.eng: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn15.8:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn15.8:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and asked the Buddha,

sn15.8:1.4.pli: “kīvabahukā nu kho, bho gotama, kappā abbhatītā atikkantā”ti?
sn15.8:1.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, how many eons have passed?”

sn15.8:1.7.pli: ‘ettakā kappā iti vā, ettakāni kappasatāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasatasahassāni iti vā’”ti.
sn15.8:1.7.eng: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.”

sn15.8:2.1.eng: “But worthy Gotama, can you give a simile?”

sn15.8:2.3.pli: “Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇa, yato cāyaṃ gaṅgā nadī pabhavati yattha ca mahāsamuddaṃ appeti, yā etasmiṃ antare vālikā sā na sukarā saṅkhātuṃ:
sn15.8:2.3.eng: “Consider the Ganges river from where it originates to where it meets the ocean. Between these places it’s not easy to calculate

sn15.8:2.4.pli: ‘ettakā vālikā iti vā, ettakāni vālikasatāni iti vā, ettakāni vālikasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni vālikasatasahassāni iti vā’ti.
sn15.8:2.4.eng: how many grains of sand there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.

sn15.8:2.5.pli: Tato bahutarā kho, brāhmaṇa, kappā abbhatītā atikkantā.
sn15.8:2.5.eng: The eons that have passed are more than this.

sn15.8:2.7.pli: ‘ettakā kappā iti vā, ettakāni kappasatāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni kappasatasahassāni iti vā’ti.
sn15.8:2.7.eng: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.

sn15.8:2.9.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.8:2.10.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.8:2.10.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.8:2.11.pli: Evaṃ dīgharattaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, dukkhaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ tibbaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ byasanaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ, kaṭasī vaḍḍhitā.
sn15.8:2.11.eng: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.

sn15.8:2.12.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, brāhmaṇa, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ, alaṃ virajjituṃ, alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.8:2.12.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.8:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn15.8:3.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha,

sn15.8:3.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn15.8:3.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn15.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.9:1.3.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.9:1.3.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.9:1.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, daṇḍo uparivehāsaṃ khitto sakimpi mūlena nipatati, sakimpi majjhena nipatati, sakimpi antena nipatati;
sn15.9:1.4.eng: Suppose a stick was tossed up in the air. Sometimes it’d fall on its bottom, sometimes the middle, and sometimes the end.

sn15.9:1.5.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjānīvaraṇā sattā taṇhāsaṃyojanā sandhāvantā saṃsarantā sakimpi asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ gacchanti, sakimpi parasmā lokā imaṃ lokaṃ āgacchanti.
sn15.9:1.5.eng: It’s the same for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving. Sometimes they go from this world to the other world, and sometimes they come from the other world to this world.

sn15.9:1.7.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.9:1.8.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
